oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Interview with Debbie Healy Hammons: Alumni Stories
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hammons, Deborah (interviewee) (Creator)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Debbie Healy Hammons (BA English, 1973) shares memories of coming to Stanford from Wyoming, living in Toyon during her freshman year, and the political unrest related to the Vietnam War that she witnessed on campus and in the Bay Area. She relates stories of listening to the draft lottery on the radio, hearing windows breaking, the cancellation of classes during spring quarter of her freshman year, and standing in between riot police and students during a protest. She also reflects on the co-existence of two cultural worlds at Stanford, describing co-ed dorms, freedom from rules, and access to birth control on the one hand, and the persistence of the “dolly” culture on the other, with women wearing traditionally feminine dress and makeup. Hammons also remarks on the way clothing acted as a signal for group belonging and touches on her experiences in creative writing in the English Department, being involved in theater, and returning to Wyoming after college.

Debbie and her husband Greg, who lived their adult lives and raised their two sons in Wyoming, recently retired to Colorado. Debbie wrote, hosted and produced over ninety programs for Wyoming PBS, including Main Street, Wyoming and the award-winning Wyoming Voices, which featured over 100 interviews of Wyoming residents and continues to be used to teach Wyoming history in the state's community colleges and high schools. In addition, Debbie served twelve years on the University of Wyoming Board of Trustees, two years as Board President. She represented House District 27 as a member of the Wyoming House of Representatives for three terms, 2004-2010. In addition to her position as Minority Whip, she co-authored the Hathaway and Higher Education Endowment Bill, which created an endowment to pay the tuition for Wyoming students who study a pre-college curriculum. Debbie remains a passionate proponent for opportunities for all, and currently serves as Chairman, Public Policy Committee, Women's Foundation of Colorado. She earned a BA in English and Creative Writing from Stanford University in 1973 and a master's degree in Applied Positive Psychology from the University of Pennsylvania in 2013.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Hammons, Deborah
Stanford University
Universities and colleges
College students
oai_dc:dc.dc:relation: Stanford University. Libraries. Department of Special Collections and University Archives
Stanford Historical Society Oral History Program interviews, 1999-2013 (inclusive)

mods.abstract: Debbie Healy Hammons (BA English, 1973) shares memories of coming to Stanford from Wyoming, living in Toyon during her freshman year, and the political unrest related to the Vietnam War that she witnessed on campus and in the Bay Area. She relates stories of listening to the draft lottery on the radio, hearing windows breaking, the cancellation of classes during spring quarter of her freshman year, and standing in between riot police and students during a protest. She also reflects on the co-existence of two cultural worlds at Stanford, describing co-ed dorms, freedom from rules, and access to birth control on the one hand, and the persistence of the “dolly” culture on the other, with women wearing traditionally feminine dress and makeup. Hammons also remarks on the way clothing acted as a signal for group belonging and touches on her experiences in creative writing in the English Department, being involved in theater, and returning to Wyoming after college.
mods.note: Debbie and her husband Greg, who lived their adult lives and raised their two sons in Wyoming, recently retired to Colorado. Debbie wrote, hosted and produced over ninety programs for Wyoming PBS, including Main Street, Wyoming and the award-winning Wyoming Voices, which featured over 100 interviews of Wyoming residents and continues to be used to teach Wyoming history in the state's community colleges and high schools. In addition, Debbie served twelve years on the University of Wyoming Board of Trustees, two years as Board President. She represented House District 27 as a member of the Wyoming House of Representatives for three terms, 2004-2010. In addition to her position as Minority Whip, she co-authored the Hathaway and Higher Education Endowment Bill, which created an endowment to pay the tuition for Wyoming students who study a pre-college curriculum. Debbie remains a passionate proponent for opportunities for all, and currently serves as Chairman, Public Policy Committee, Women's Foundation of Colorado. She earned a BA in English and Creative Writing from Stanford University in 1973 and a master's degree in Applied Positive Psychology from the University of Pennsylvania in 2013.
